<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_linux_bus_close:
```c
static void metal_linux_bus_close(struct metal_bus *bus)
{
	struct linux_bus *lbus = to_linux_bus(bus);
	struct linux_driver *ldrv;

	for_each_linux_driver(lbus, ldrv) {
		if (ldrv->sdrv)
			sysfs_close_driver(ldrv->sdrv);
		ldrv->sdrv = NULL;
	}

	sysfs_close_bus(lbus->sbus);
	lbus->sbus = NULL;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function metal_linux_bus_close:
struct linux_bus {
	struct metal_bus	bus;
	const char		*bus_name;
	struct linux_driver	drivers[MAX_DRIVERS];
	struct sysfs_bus	*sbus;
}
...
struct linux_driver {
	const char		*drv_name;
	const char		*mod_name;
	const char		*cls_name;
	struct sysfs_driver	*sdrv;
	int			(*dev_open)(struct linux_bus *lbus,
					    struct linux_device *ldev);
	void			(*dev_close)(struct linux_bus *lbus,
					     struct linux_device *ldev);
	void			(*dev_irq_ack)(struct linux_bus *lbus,
					     struct linux_device *ldev,
					     int irq);
	int			(*dev_dma_map)(struct linux_bus *lbus,
						struct linux_device *ldev,
						uint32_t dir,
						struct metal_sg *sg_in,
						int nents_in,
						struct metal_sg *sg_out);
	void			(*dev_dma_unmap)(struct linux_bus *lbus,
						struct linux_device *ldev,
						uint32_t dir,
						struct metal_sg *sg,
						int nents);
}
...
#define for_each_linux_driver(lbus, ldrv) for((ldrv)=lbus->drivers;(ldrv)->drv_name;(ldrv)++)
...
static struct linux_bus *to_linux_bus(struct metal_bus *bus)
{
	return metal_container_of(bus, struct linux_bus, bus);
}
...
struct metal_bus {
	const char		*name;
	struct metal_bus_ops	ops;
	struct metal_list	devices;
	struct metal_list	node;
}
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
struct linux_driver		drivers[MAX_DRIVERS];
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 2.1 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No unreachable code is present. The fragment declares an array of driver structures (data), not code. The for_each_linux_driver macro iterates over this array using a sentinel (drv_name) so loop body is reachable for each populated element; there are no statements that can never be executed. (A violation would occur only if there were code after an unconditional return/abort or similar unreachable branch, which is not the case here.)
